section.title: Setting the Initial Epoch
section.para: You can configure the initial epoch of a spacecraft in several time systems (TAI, TDB, UTC, etc) and formats (Gregorian, modified Julian). To set the epoch in UTC Gregorian, follow these steps starting from the default mission:

step.para: In the Resources tree, double-click DefaultSC to open its properties window.
Click the Orbit tab if it isn't already selected.
In the Epoch Format list, select UTCGregorian.
In the Epoch box, type 04 Jul 2014 09:30:15.235. This field is case-sensitive, and must be entered in the exact format shown.
Click OK or Apply to save your changes.

section.para: The GMAT script for the epoch settings configured above is:
section.programlisting: Create Spacecraft DefaultSC DefaultSC.DateFormat = UTCGregorian DefaultSC.Epoch = '04 Jul 2014 09:30:15.235'

section.title: Configuring the Orbit
section.para: You can set the orbit of a spacecraft in several representations, such as Keplerian and Cartesian, and in any of the default or user-created coordinate systems. Starting from the default mission, first set the initial epoch:

step.para: In the Resources tree, right-click on DefaultSC and click Rename.
In the Rename box type ISS and click OK.
In the Resources tree, double-click ISS to open its properties window.
Click the Orbit tab if it isn't already selected.
In the Epoch Format list, click UTCGregorian.
In the Epoch box, type 21 Oct 2011 14:01:29.130.

section.para: Now set the orbital state for ISS:

step.para: In the State Type list, click Keplerian.
In the SMA box, type 6771.907.
In the ECC box, type 0.00103.
In the INC box, type 51.597.
In the RAAN box, type 244.300.
In the AOP box, type 353.735.
In the TA box, type 199.683.
Click OK.

section.para: The GMAT script for the spacecraft state configured above is:
section.programlisting: Create Spacecraft ISS ISS.DateFormat = UTCGregorian ISS.Epoch = 21 Oct 2011 14:01:29.130 ISS.SMA = 6771.907 ISS.ECC = 0.00103 ISS.INC = 51.597 ISS.RAAN = 244.300 ISS.AOP = 353.735 ISS.TA = 199.683

section.title: Configuring Physical Properties
section.para: GMAT allows you to set the physical properties of a spacecraft, such as the mass and area. Starting from the default mission:

step.para: In the Resources tree, double-click on DefaultSC to open its properties window.
Click the Ballistic/Mass tab.
In the Dry Mass box, type 450.
In the Coefficient of Drag box, type 2.0.
In the Coefficient of Reflectivity box, type 1.7.
In the Drag Area box, type 10.5.
In the SRP Area box, type 12.5.
Click OK or Apply to save your changes.

section.para: The script for the physical settings configured above is shown below.
section.programlisting: Create Spacecraft DefaultSC DefaultSC.DryMass = 450 DefaultSC.Cd = 2.0 DefaultSC.Cr = 1.7 DefaultSC.DragArea = 10.5 DefaultSC.SRPArea = 12.5

section.title: Configuring the Attitude (Fixed)
section.para: GMAT can model a spacecraft with an attitude fixed in any defined coordinate system, including user-defined systems. This can be used to model nadir-pointing or inertially-pointed spacecraft.

For example, follow these instructions to set the attitude of the default spacecraft using Euler angle rotations from the built-in EarthMJ2000Eq inertial coordinate system. Starting from the default mission:

step.para: In the Resources tree, double-click DefaultSC to open its properties window.
Click the Attitude tab.
In the Attitude Model list, select CoordinateSystemFixed.
In the Coordinate System list, select EarthMJ2000Eq.
In the Attitude Initial Conditions area, in the Attitude State Type box, select Euler Angles.
In the Euler Angle 1 box, type 123.
In the Euler Angle 2 box, type 45.
In the Euler Angle 3 box, type 157.
Click OK or Apply to save your changes.

section.para: The script for the settings configured above is shown below.
section.programlisting: Create Spacecraft DefaultSC DefaultSC.Attitude = CoordinateSystemFixed DefaultSC.AttitudeCoordinateSystem = 'EarthMJ2000Eq' DefaultSC.EulerAngle1 = 123 DefaultSC.EulerAngle2 = 45 DefaultSC.EulerAngle3 = 157

section.title: Configuring the Attitude (Spinner)
section.para: GMAT has a special attitude model that makes it easy to set up a spacecraft that spins about the axes of any defined coordinate system. The steps below define a spacecraft-centered coordinate system with axes rotating with the Sun-Earth line, then define a spacecraft as spinning about the X-axis of that system. Starting from the default mission:
First, define the Solar coordinate system:

step.para: In the Resources tree, right click Coordinate Systems and click Add Coordinate System.
In the Coordinate System Name box, type Solar.
In the Origin list, select DefaultSC.
In the Type list, select ObjectReferenced.
Set the Primary body to Sun, and the Secondary body to Earth.
Set the X axis to -R and the Z axis to N. Leave the Y axis at its default blank value.
Click OK or Apply to save your changes.

section.para: Now set the default spacecraft to spin about the X-axis of the Solar coordinate system:

step.para: In the Resources tree, double-click DefaultSC to open its properties window.
Click the Attitude tab.
In the Attitude Model list, select Spinner. This enables the Attitude Rate Initial Conditions properties.
In the Coordinate System list, select Solar.
In the Euler Angle Sequence box, select 123. This maps the first Euler angle rotation to the X-axis of the coordinate system.
In the Attitude Rate State Type list, select EulerAngleRates.
In the Euler Angle Rate 1 box, type 180.
Click OK or Apply to save your changes.

section.para: The script for the settings configured above is shown below.
section.programlisting: Create Spacecraft DefaultSC DefaultSC.Attitude = Spinner DefaultSC.AttitudeCoordinateSystem = 'Solar' DefaultSC.EulerAngleSequence = '123' DefaultSC.EulerAngleRate1 = 180 DefaultSC.EulerAngleRate2 = 0 DefaultSC.EulerAngleRate3 = 0
